title-group.article-title: New Caddisflies (Insecta, Trichoptera) from the Krabi and Phang Nga Provinces southern Thailand

sec.p: New Caddisflies (Insecta, Trichoptera ) from the Krabi and Phang Nga Provinces, southern Thailand
HANS MALICKY1 , VLADIMIR D. IVANOV 2,* & STANISLAV I. MELNITSKY3
1 Sonnengasse 13, 3293 Lunz am See, Austria
2 Department of Entomology, Faculty of Biology, St. Petersburg State University,
Universitetskaya nab., St. Petersburg 199034, Russia v--ivanov@yandex.ru
3 Department of Entomology, Faculty of Biology, St. Petersburg State University,
Universitetskaya nab., St. Petersburg 199034, Russia simelnitsky@gmail.com
*corresponding author

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p: An updated list of the caddisfly species occurring in Krabi and Phang Nga Provinces, southern Thailand , comprises 76 species. Among them, 69 species are found in Krabi Province and 17 inPhang Nga Province , 4 are new for science and 2 new for Thailand . New species from the families Hydroptilidae ( Hydroptila nevdomek sp. n. ), Polycentropodidae ( Nyctiophylax dosyhpor sp.n. ), Psychomyiidae ( Psychomyia dabudettak sp. n. ), and Leptoceridae ( Setodes pokamest sp. n. ) are described. Hydroptila namcattienMalicky & Chantaramongkol 2007 and Setodes kybeleMalicky & Chantaramongkol 2006 are new species for Thailand . Faunistic considerations and comparisons to other regions of Thailand are provided.

Key words:Hydroptilidae , Polycentropodidae , Psychomyiidae , Leptoceridae , Hydroptila , Nyctiophylax , Psychomyia , Setodes ,
systematics, fauna

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Recent publications on the caddisflies fauna of Thailand suggest a very abundant species composition comprising more than 1000 species from 31 families and 106 genera (
Chantaramongkol et al. 2010
; Malicky 2010 , 2011 , 2012 ; Laudee & Malicky 2014 ). Dominant families are Leptoceridae , Hydropsychidae , and Hydroptilidae . Recent findings provide significantly high numbers of new species, demonstrating inadequate knowledge of Trichoptera in southern Thailand . Oriental faunas of Trichoptera are the richest among all zoogeographic realms ( de Moor & Ivanov 2008 ; Morse 2016 ) and known species diversity in Trichoptera decreases from the continental mainland towards remote faunas of the Sunda Islands (
Malicky et al. 2014
). Biodiversity of Trichoptera was estimated by Schmid (1984) to be most abundant in the “Oriental Region”. The Trichoptera faunal diversity of Thailand seems to be compatible with that of India (816 species, Higler 1992 ) and China (1267 species,
Yang et al . 2016
), although human impact in these three countries obscures the primary diversitybecause the natural landscapes have been lost in most lowland parts of Southeast Asia. Inadequate knowledge of faunas in neighboring countries like Myanmar , Laos , and Cambodia prevents a detailed comparison of countries. New species can be easily discovered even in better studied countries like Thailand .

This publication presents new data based on a small collection from southern Thailand sampled during a short time period in the winter dry season, 2014. Possibly there are other species because we consider only the adults and did not study the immatures. The collection includes 4 species new for science and several new faunal records. In total, 76 species were determined from 8 localities. Cumulative data on Trichoptera will eventually provide a basis for comparative analysis of faunas and an understanding of biodiversity changes. Besides, a knowledge of caddisfly faunas will help to improve water quality monitoringtechniques.

sec.title: Material and Methods
sec.p: LOCALITY 1: THAILAND , Krabi Province , 19 km WNW from Krabi , brook, 08º05’43”N , 98º44’49”E , 10 m above sea level (m a.s.l.), UV light traps, 5 February 2014 , leg. Melnitsky, Ivanov.

LOCALITY 2 (
): THAILAND , Krabi Province , 40 km SE from Krabi , small river, 07º55’46”N , 99º13’24”E , 30 m a.s.l., UV light traps, 3 February 2014 , leg. Melnitsky, Ivanov.
LOCALITY 3: THAILAND , Krabi Province , 12 km N from Krabi City, Krabi River, 08º11’24”N , 98º52’37”E , 40 m a.s.l., UV light traps, 30 January 2014 , leg. Melnitsky, Ivanov.

LOCALITY 4 (
): THAILAND , Krabi Province , 18 km N from Krabi , waterfall, 08º14’21”N , 98º55’17”E , 320 m a.s.l., UV light traps, 31 January 2014 , leg. Melnitsky, Ivanov.

LOCALITY 5 (
): THAILAND , Krabi Province , 15 km NNE from Krabi , river, 08º12’30”N , 98º56’14”E , 60 m a.s.l., UV light traps, 1 February 2014 , leg. Melnitsky, Ivanov.

LOCALITY 6 (
): THAILAND , Phang Nga Province , 7 km NNE from Phang Nga , Sa Nang Manora waterfall, 08º30’39”N , 98º32’32”E , 110 m a.s.l., UV light traps, 6 February 2014 , leg. Melnitsky.

LOCALITY 7 (
): THAILAND , Phang Nga Province , 7 km NE from Phang Nga , river, 08º29’10”N , 98º35’09”E , 30 m a.s.l., by net, 6 February 2014 , leg. Melnitsky.
LOCALITY 8: THAILAND , Krabi Province , small river in forest, 08º14’38” N , 98º57’41” E , 150 m a.s.l., UV light traps, 2 February 2014 , leg. Ivanov.

mixed-citation.named-content: New Caddisflies (Insecta, Trichoptera) from the Krabi and Phang Nga Provinces southern Thailand

tp:treatment-sec.p: Holotype : male. Wings and larger part of body yellow fuscous; head, prothorax, antennae yellow. Length of each forewing 4 mm .

Male genitalia. Ventral part of segment IX in lateral view trapezoid. Superior appendages large and round in lateral view. Segment X in lateral view narrow, finger-like; in dorsal view triangular, acutely bilobed apically. Mesoventral process of each superior appendage hook-like, short, with wide base and narrow apex turned downwards. Inferior appendages in lateral view each with small rounded ventral branch and larger tapering dorsal branch with parallel sides and acute apex; in ventral view, with short, rectangular ventral and long, gradually narrowed dorsal branches. Phallus with two pairs of very long spines: dorsal pair (probable parameres) slender and long, directed posterad; ventral pair massive, half as long as dorsal pair, and curved ventrolaterad. Seven strong subparallel ventral spines in apical third of phallus directed posteroventrad.

Diagnosis. Male genitalia of this new species are similar to those of Nyctiophylax argentensisMalicky 1995a from Vietnam , differing from the latter in the shape of the inferior appendages (each of which has a more-acute dorsal branch and a more-prominent ventral branch), very strong serial spines on the phallus (finer and more numerous in N . argentensis ), and a more-slender mesoventral part of each superior appendage.

p.tp:material-citation: Holotype : THAILAND , Krabi Province , 18 km N from Krabi , waterfall, 08º14’21”N , 98º55’17”E , height 320 m , UV light traps, 31 January 2014 , leg. Melnitsky , Ivanov. (Locality 4)

tp:treatment-sec.p: Distribution.Thailand (known only from type locality).
Etymology. An indeclinable name with gender agreement irrelevant, from the Russian do syh por (up to now).
Holotype : male. Wings and body yellow-brown, length of each forewing 2.5 mm .

Male genitalia.Anterolateral margins of segment IX in lateral view round. Dorsal complex including segment X and superior appendages short; in dorsal view shaped as bird heads with elongate, acute, projecting beaks directed mesad; with numerous setae along internal margins. Inferior appendages each with 3 branches: (1) larger, finger-like ventrolateral branch directed downwards; (2, 3) two narrow dorsomesal branches curved downward; branches of opposing inferior appendages acute and asymmetrical as shown on
. Phallus with 2 subapical lobes aligned successively on the ventral midline.

Diagnosis. Male genitalia of this species are similar to those of P. amorMalicky & Chantaramongkol 1997 , P. amphiaraosMalicky & Chantaramongkol 1997 , P. sinonMalicky & Prommi 2006 , and P. kalaisMalicky 2004 with superior appendages mimicking bird’s heads in dorsal or ventral views. The new species differs from all of them in the peculiar asymmetrical design of the inferior appendages, also in the larger ventral, subapical lobes of the phallus (small in P. amphiaraos , absent in P. amor , P. sinon ,
and P. kalais ). Superior appendages of the new species have no basal teeth visible from above whereas these teeth are present in P. kalais , P. amor ,
and P. amphiaraos ; the basal parts of the superior appendages in P. sinon also have no teeth, but superior appendages in the new species are more slender, without basal dilations.

p.tp:material-citation: Holotype : THAILAND , Krabi Province , 18 km N from Krabi , waterfall, 08º14’21”N , 98º55’17”E , height 320 m , UV light traps, 31 January 2014 , leg. Melnitsky , Ivanov. (Locality 4)

tp:treatment-sec.p: Distribution.Thailand (known only from type locality).
Etymology. An indeclinable name with gender agreement irrelevant, from the Russian da budet tak (let it be so).
Holotype : male. Wings and body yellow brown. Length of each forewing 2 mm .

Male genitalia. Anterolateral margins of segment IX in lateral view acutely angulate 60°, this segment deeply incised in dorsal and ventral views. Segment X in lateral view long and abruptly narrowed, tapering posteriorly; in dorsal view trapezoidal, prominently narrowing in caudal part, with slightly convex lateral margins in basal 3/4. Inferior appendages in lateral view long, relatively wide and straight and parallel-sided proximally, wider and slightly curved upward in distal part; in ventral view divergent, thin and pointed, with small basal pieces separated by sutures. Subgenital plate slim, elongate, acute, and slightly bent. Phallus very long, with paramere at mid length forming 2 semispirals (proximal and distal, separated by rectilinear part) and directed ventrocaudad apically, and phallus with large apical tooth projecting dorsad at right angle.

Diagnosis. Simplified genital structures with lamellate inferior appendages, roof-like wide segment X with obtuse apex, well developed long paramere suggest this species to be related to the Hydroptila sparsa species complex. This species differs from numerous related similar species in the angled shape of the anterior margins of segment IX; in the distinctively clavate inferior appendages; in the large apical tooth of the phallus with a characteristically bent, long paramere extending to the middle of the terminal part of the phallus; and in the abruptly narrower configuration of segment X in dorsal view, without any species particularly similar to it in these characters.

p.tp:material-citation: Holotype : THAILAND , Krabi Province , 18 km N from Krabi , waterfall, 08º14’21”N , 98º55’17”E , height 320 m , UV light traps, 31 January 2014 , leg. Melnitsky , Ivanov. (Locality 4)

tp:treatment-sec.p: Distribution.Thailand (known only from type locality).
Etymology. An indeclinable name with gender agreement irrelevant, from the Russian nevdomek (incomprehension).

p.tp:material-citation: Holotype : male. Completely light yellow except for black eyes. No color patterns on wings visible in insects preserved in alcohol. Hind wing vein M with 2 branches (MA and MP ). Length of each forewing 5.5 mm .

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Diagnosis. The male genitalia of this species described above is similar to those of Setodes melpomene Malicky & Chantaromongkol 2006
, in that the phallic complex is very similar (
), and its apical parts also are antisymmetrical, directed either to the right or to the left; 9 studied specimens showed 2 right- and 7 left-oriented parameres. However, the latter has no long, acute caudal projections of segment X and the ventral part of each inferior appendage is not three-lobed, but approximately quadrangular ( Malicky 2010 , p. 322). Other similar species, S. likymnios Malicky & Nuntakwang 2006
(in Malicky & Chantaramongkol 2006 ) differs in simplified gonopods with fewer projections, in more-slender parameres, and in acute caudal projections of segment X more robust and curved ventrad.

p.tp:material-citation: Holotype : THAILAND , Krabi Province , 40 km SE from Krabi , small river, 07º55’46”N , 99º13’24”E , height 30 m , UV light traps, 3 February 2014 , leg. Melnitsky , Ivanov.

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Paratypes : 39 males from the same locality
.
Distribution.Thailand (known only from type locality).
Etymology. An indeclinable name with gender agreement irrelevant, from the Russian pokamest (meanwhile).

mixed-citation.named-content: New Caddisflies (Insecta, Trichoptera) from the Krabi and Phang Nga Provinces southern Thailand

and P. kalais ). Superior appendages of the new species have no basal teeth visible from above whereas these teeth are present in P. kalais , P. amor ,
and P. amphiaraos ; the basal parts of the superior appendages in P. sinon also have no teeth, but superior appendages in the new species are more slender, without basal dilations.

p.tp:material-citation: Holotype : THAILAND , Krabi Province , 18 km N from Krabi , waterfall, 08º14’21”N , 98º55’17”E , height 320 m , UV light traps, 31 January 2014 , leg. Melnitsky , Ivanov. (Locality 4)

tp:treatment-sec.p: Distribution.Thailand (known only from type locality).
Etymology. An indeclinable name with gender agreement irrelevant, from the Russian da budet tak (let it be so).
Holotype : male. Wings and body yellow brown. Length of each forewing 2 mm .

Male genitalia. Anterolateral margins of segment IX in lateral view acutely angulate 60°, this segment deeply incised in dorsal and ventral views. Segment X in lateral view long and abruptly narrowed, tapering posteriorly; in dorsal view trapezoidal, prominently narrowing in caudal part, with slightly convex lateral margins in basal 3/4. Inferior appendages in lateral view long, relatively wide and straight and parallel-sided proximally, wider and slightly curved upward in distal part; in ventral view divergent, thin and pointed, with small basal pieces separated by sutures. Subgenital plate slim, elongate, acute, and slightly bent. Phallus very long, with paramere at mid length forming 2 semispirals (proximal and distal, separated by rectilinear part) and directed ventrocaudad apically, and phallus with large apical tooth projecting dorsad at right angle.

Diagnosis. Simplified genital structures with lamellate inferior appendages, roof-like wide segment X with obtuse apex, well developed long paramere suggest this species to be related to the Hydroptila sparsa species complex. This species differs from numerous related similar species in the angled shape of the anterior margins of segment IX; in the distinctively clavate inferior appendages; in the large apical tooth of the phallus with a characteristically bent, long paramere extending to the middle of the terminal part of the phallus; and in the abruptly narrower configuration of segment X in dorsal view, without any species particularly similar to it in these characters.

p.tp:material-citation: Holotype : THAILAND , Krabi Province , 18 km N from Krabi , waterfall, 08º14’21”N , 98º55’17”E , height 320 m , UV light traps, 31 January 2014 , leg. Melnitsky , Ivanov. (Locality 4)

tp:treatment-sec.p: Distribution.Thailand (known only from type locality).
Etymology. An indeclinable name with gender agreement irrelevant, from the Russian nevdomek (incomprehension).

p.tp:material-citation: Holotype : male. Completely light yellow except for black eyes. No color patterns on wings visible in insects preserved in alcohol. Hind wing vein M with 2 branches (MA and MP ). Length of each forewing 5.5 mm .

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Diagnosis. The male genitalia of this species described above is similar to those of Setodes melpomene Malicky & Chantaromongkol 2006
, in that the phallic complex is very similar (
), and its apical parts also are antisymmetrical, directed either to the right or to the left; 9 studied specimens showed 2 right- and 7 left-oriented parameres. However, the latter has no long, acute caudal projections of segment X and the ventral part of each inferior appendage is not three-lobed, but approximately quadrangular ( Malicky 2010 , p. 322). Other similar species, S. likymnios Malicky & Nuntakwang 2006
(in Malicky & Chantaramongkol 2006 ) differs in simplified gonopods with fewer projections, in more-slender parameres, and in acute caudal projections of segment X more robust and curved ventrad.

p.tp:material-citation: Holotype : THAILAND , Krabi Province , 40 km SE from Krabi , small river, 07º55’46”N , 99º13’24”E , height 30 m , UV light traps, 3 February 2014 , leg. Melnitsky , Ivanov.

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Paratypes : 39 males from the same locality
.
Distribution.Thailand (known only from type locality).
Etymology. An indeclinable name with gender agreement irrelevant, from the Russian pokamest (meanwhile).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our investigation represents the primary data on fauna of caddisflies from 2 southern adjoining provinces of Thailand , Krabi and Phang Nga . Nevertheless, the limited sampling discovered significant taxonomic diversity of Trichoptera : 13 families, 31 genera, and 76 species. Comparison with the available information published for the neighboring province Surat Thani ( Laudee & Prommi 2011 ) shows 25 shared species (33%). Distance from our sampling area to the Tapee River basin ( Surat Thani Province ) was less than 70 km of uniform plain and hill landscape; hence these 2 territories might represent the same faunistic region.

According to our unpublished data (Malicky et al . in preparation), a substantial similarity was found also in Phuket Province sharing 21 species (30%) with Krabi and Phang Nga Provinces. Probably these provinces have much more similarity because the available data were obtained for local places investigated during short periods of time.

Trapping methods in our brief study and that of Laudee & Prommi (2011) were different. In contrast with their technique of manually picking specimens from an illuminated screen, our light traps collected numerous insects and we did not select specimens when using them. As a result, the data we obtained on the local fauna, including the relative abundances of different species, should be representative for the sampling point and time of year. Thus, any differences between 2 or more localities sampled by our method at closely proximate dates should suggest an objective disparity in local faunas.

In this context, we note the differences of species composition in the Provinces of Krabi and Phang Nga . Almost half of the Phang Nga species were sampled only in the latter province: Pahamunaya taleban ( Malicky & Chantaramongkol 1993b )
, Helicopsyche anaksakuMalicky 1995b , Ecnomus neriMalicky & Chantaramongkol 1993a , Ecnomus plaiwatMalicky & Chantaramongkol 1993b , Paduniella tigridisMalicky & Chantaramongkol 1993b , Tinodes jichaMalicky & Chantaramongkol 1989 , and Cheumatopsyche criseydeMalicky & Chantaramongkol 1997 (in Malicky 1997) (7 of 17 species found in the province).

One could expect that most, if not all species from Krabi Province should occur also in Surat Thani due to the short distance between sampling areas with similar environments. Comparison of data published by Laudee & Prommi (2011) and our results contradicts this assumption: Only 36% of the 69 species found in Krabi are shared between the two areas.

Significantly fewer species indicate similarity to more remote faunas of Thailand . For example, only 5 of 24 (21%) species found on Ko Chang Island, 560 km from Krabi in eastern part of the Gulf of Thailand , at the same season in similar streams ( Melnitsky & Malicky 2008 ), were recorded also from Krabi . These species are Oxyethira bogambaraSchmid 1958 , Chimarra okuihorumMey 1998 , Cheumatopsyche chrysothemisMalicky & Chantaramongkol 1997 (in Malicky 1997), and Setodes thonetiMalicky & Chantaramongkol 2006 ; these 4 species are widespread in Southeast Asia and the Pacific islands.

Comparison of the Trichoptera found in the Krabi Province to fauna of neighboring Surat Thani Province studied by Laudee & Prommi (2011) shows unexpected disparity at the family level. Indeed, our data on Krabi and Phang Nga Provinces are from only the middle of the dry cool season and do not show the species emerging during other seasons. Families Rhyacophilidae , Stenopsychidae , Brachycentridae , Lepidostomatidae , Calamoceratidae could be absent in Krabi and Phang Nga samples for this reason. In contrast, absence of Xiphocentronidae and the low diversity of Hydroptilidae and Polycentropodidae in Surat Thani Province according to Laudee & Prommi (2011) , is less expected. Families Philopotamidae , Psychomyiidae , and Ecnomidae show very large differences in local faunas, although the species diversity of these families ( Laudee & Prommi 2011 ) is similar to our data. The families with stronger likelihood of dispersal flight of adults, like Hydropsychidae and Leptoceridae , contributed significantly fewer shared species in Surat Thani , with approximately half of the species also found in Krabi and Phang Nga for each family. The Krabi samples were taken from smaller streams, whereas the significant part of Surat Thani data was collected from larger streams, with the domination of Ecnomidae , Dipseudopsidae , Hydropsy- chidae. Leptoceridae ; therefore, their findings are not comparable to our results. Nonetheless even the upper streams in the two neighboring areas show apparent differences. Probably the material collected so far in southern Thailand is only a modest fraction of the total Trichoptera biodiversity in this area.

Data from the neighboring province, Nakhon Si Thammarat , including the local mountain range, comprise 75 Trichoptera species ( Laudee & Malicky 2014 ). These samples were made during a few field trips in spring 2014 (dry hot season). A comparison of faunas shows that there are 12 species shared with Krabi (17%) and 5 shared with Phang Nga (29%). Surat Thani and Nakhon Si Thammarat have 28 species present in both faunas (27% of the total Surat Thani species). These results are surprising because in the latter instance the mountains are the same Nakhon Si Thammarat range represented by its northern and eastern slopes. All these comparisons reveal unusually consistent low similarity of shared species, around 30%. We believe that this low similarity of faunas might be caused by insufficient sampling. More specimens obtained in the future might increase the similarity among provinces to 50–70%. Currently, however, the composition of Trichoptera faunas in southern Thailand looks very mosaic.

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p: Authors are thankful to Ferdinand de Moor and an anonymous reviewer for their important suggestions and questions helping to correct the descriptions and the Editor, Dr. J. Morse, for his invaluable comments and proposals for text improvements. The reported study was funded by RFBR, project number 18-04-00312. The research has been supported also by Saint Petersburg State University grants 1.42.1686.2011, 1.42.289.2012, 1.42.506.2013, 1.42.1278.2014, 1.42.1017.2016, and 1.42.1011.2016.
